DOC.HEAD: Six Killed in Interstate Chain Pileup Outside Flagstaff
Eds: SUBS grafs 8-10, bgng `Six people...', with 3 grafs to UPDATE with initial death toll revised downward to five, but 14-year-old girl then dying; Pick up 9th graf, `At least ...'
DOC.TEXT: A chain of collisions on an icy, fogbound interstate outside Flagstaff left six people dead and at least 34 injured Saturday, authorities said. Another series of collisions on a foggy stretch of interstate in northern Florida injured 15 people, one seriously. The mid-morning accidents in Arizona involved about 40 vehicles, including 16 to 18 tractor trailers, said Sgt. Allan Schmidt, a spokesman for the Arizona Department of Public Safety. There were at least three separate accident sites over a quarter-mile stretch of Interstate 40 about five miles east of Flagstaff in northern Arizona, officials said. Emergency personnel and equipment were brought in from as far away as Kingman, 160 miles to the west. ``This is the all-time worst accident that I've ever personally witnessed,'' said Coconino County Sheriff Joe Richards, a 17-year veteran. ``The extensive amount of injuries, damage and death, it's almost unbelieveable. It's nightmarish in its magnitude.'' Schmidt initially said six people were confirmed dead, but Flagstaff Fire Capt. Paul Hellenberg revised that figure downward to five, including three people whose bodies were pulled from a car trapped between three tractor-trailer rigs. Then an unidentified 14-year-old girl who was freed from the same car after more than five hours died of her injuries in a hospital, bringing the toll back up to six, Hellenberg said. Thirty-three other people were taken to Flagstaff Medical Center with injuries, hospital spokeswoman Lauren Bosse said. Ten people were treated and released, she said. Bosse said she did not know the conditions or injuries of the others. At least six people were injured seriously, Fire Capt. Mike Giovando said. The accidents closed the eastbound lanes of I-40, heading toward Albuquerque, N.M., for the day. Westbound lanes were reopened a couple of hours after the accidents. Traffic was backed up for several miles and had to be rerouted. Officials said they were investigating the cause. Giovando, one of the first authorities on the scene, said the accidents apparently were the result of icy roads and fog. Up to 2 feet of snow has fallen in Flagstaff since Thursday night. ``It was a real heavy fog,'' Giovando said. ``We were trying to get a hose line, then we heard people screaming that they were being burned by the fire.'' One truck was destroyed by fire, officials said. A shelter for survivors was set up at a local elementary school. In Florida, four chain-reaction collisions involving 25 vehicles closed Interstate 95 for more than two hours in both directions just south of the Georgia border, the Florida Highway Patrol said. Nine people were taken to hospitals, including a 5-year-old boy who was in serious condition in the pediatric intensive care unit of Baptist Hospital in Jacksonville, nurse Bonnie Lundblom said. The boy's younger brother, believed to be about 18 months old, was in stable condition and ``doing fine,'' Lundblom said. Trooper Charlie Creel said the two boys were flown to Jacksonville by helicopter.
